Class JsHTMLSelectElement

                          js.user.JsElement
                              js.dom.DOM2HTML.HTMLElement.Prototype
                                  js.user.JsHTMLElement
                                      js.dom.DOM2HTML.HTMLSelectElement.Prototype
                                          js.user.JsHTMLSelectElement
All Implemented Interfaces:
EventTarget, ObjectLike
public class JsHTMLSelectElement
extends DOM2HTML.HTMLSelectElement.Prototype

An opaque class representing JavaScript client-side objects of the global JsClient.HTMLSelectElement class.

This class represents a select menu in an HTML page, or a JsHTMLElement object created with the HTML <select> tag which creates a menu allowing the selection of an option.

The options contained in an object of this class can be directly accessed through the select element as a collection of JsHTMLOptionElement. A menu of JsHTMLSelectElement must contain at least one JsHTMLOptionElement object. If multiple is true, the user may select any number of options from the list. Otherwise, the user may select only one option, and options have a radio-button behavior, that is, selecting one deselects whichever was previously selected.

The options in an element of this class may be displayed in two distinct ways. When size is greater than 1 or multiple is true, they are displayed in a list box that is size lines high in the browser window. When size is smaller than the number of options, the listbox includes a scrollbar so all the options are accessible. On the contrary, when size is specified as 1 and multiple is false or not specified, the currently selected option is displayed on a single line, and the list of other options is made available through a drop-down menu. The first style displays the options clearly but requires more space in the browser window. The second requires minimal space but does not display alternative options explicitly.

If multiple is false or undefined, you can determine which option is selected with the selectedIndex property. Otherwise, selectedIndex tells you the index of only the first selected option. To determine the full set of selected options, you must iterate through the options array and check the JsHTMLOptionElement.selected property of each JsHTMLOptionElement object.

The options displayed by the element of this class may be dynamically modified. Add a new option with add(JsHTMLElement, JsHTMLElement). Remove an option with remove(Number). Changes can also be made by direct manipulation of the options array.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
See Also:
JsHTMLOptionElement, JsHTMLOptGroupElement
JavaScript:
Opaque types can be resolved but no class objects for them can be generated into the target codes. Re-compilers must exit with error on the operations of accessing that kind of class objects. The checkcast operation to the class literal of this interface must be ignored and instanceof to it always true.

selectedIndex

public static final Value.Number.Member selectedIndex

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLSelectElement object refers to an integer value specifying the ordinal index of the selected option, starting from 0. The value is -1 if no element is selected and is the index of the first selected option if multiple options are selected.

Setting the value of this property selects the specified option and deselects all other options, even if the JsHTMLSelectElement object has the multiple attribute specified. When you're selecting an option and when size > 1, you can deselect all options by setting selectedIndex to -1. Note that changing the selection in this way does not trigger the onchange event handler.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

type

public static final Value.String.Member type

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLSelectElement object refers to a read-only string specifying the type of this form control. It is the string "select-multiple" when the multiple attribute is true and the string "select-one" when false.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

name

public static final Value.String.Member name

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLSelectElement object refers to a string specifying the name of the input control when submitted with the form.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

size

public static final Value.Number.Member size

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLSelectElement object refers to an integer value specifying the number of visible rows, that is, the number of options to display at once.

Since:
1.0

form

public static final JsHTMLFormElement.Member form

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLSelectElement object is a read-only reference to the JsHTMLFormElement object containing the control. It is null if the control is not within the context of a form.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

options

public static final JsHTMLCollection.Member<JsHTMLOptionElement> options

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLSelectElement object is a read-only reference to the collection of JsHTMLOptionElement objects contained in the select menu, in the order in which they appear.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

onchange

public static final JsFunction.Member<?> onchange

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object is a reference to an event handler function invoked when the user selects or deselects an item.

Since:
1.0

add

public final void add(JsHTMLElement element,
                      JsHTMLElement before)

Inserts a new JsHTMLOptionElement object into the options array, either by appending it at the end of the array or by inserting it before another specified option.

Parameters:
element - The JsHTMLOptionElement object to be added.
before - The element of the options array before which the new element should be added. If this argument is null or undefined, the element is appended at the end of the options array.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if before is not a member of the options array. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.
